alert.note: Alert for Pembina (North Dakota) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Eastern ND and Grand Forks (Northeastern North Dakota and Northwestern Minnesota)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued May 01 at 9:07PM CDT until May 03 at 7:00PM CDT by NWS Eastern ND and Grand Forks
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Minnesota...North Dakota... Red River of the North at East Grand Forks affecting Polk and Grand Forks Counties. ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Minnesota...North Dakota... Red River of the North at Drayton affecting Pembina, Marshall, Walsh and Kittson Counties. Red River of the North at Pembina affecting Pembina and Kittson Counties. Red River of the North at Oslo affecting Walsh, Marshall, Polk and Grand Forks Counties. Red River of the North at Fargo affecting Cass and Clay Counties. Wild Rice River (ND) near Abercrombie affecting Richland County. Pembina River at Neche affecting Pembina County. .The Red River has crested at all sites except for Pembina and just north of Drayton. Moderate flooding will continue at Pembina and Drayton. Recessions in river stage are expected over the next few days at Oslo, Grand Forks, Fargo, Halstad, and Wahpeton. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. ...FLOOD WARNING FOR SNOWMELT REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL WEDNESDAY EVENING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Pembina River at Neche. * WHEN...Until Wednesday evening. * IMPACTS...At 19.0 feet, MODERATE FLOOD. Residential damage begins. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:45 PM CDT Monday the stage was 18.6 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 8:45 PM CDT Monday was 18.9 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage early tomorrow afternoon and continue falling to 14.8 feet Monday evening. - Flood stage is 18.0 feet. &&
info.instruction: Safety message - Turn around, don`t drown. Don`t travel through flooded areas. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely.
